docs.lead_paragraph: For women trying to decide whether to take hormone replacement after menopause, a study being published today offers new information about strokes. In one group of women, those who already have heart disease, researchers have found that hormone therapy has no effect at all on the risk of stroke. But it is not yet known whether the new findings apply to women who do not have heart disease. So far, on the subject of stroke and hormone replacement, confusion has reigned. Previous studies have had conflicting results, showing increased risk, decreased risk or no impact from hormones. But the new study, in the journal Circulation, may carry more weight than earlier ones because it was more scientifically rigorous.

headline.main: A New Look At Estrogen And Stroke

docs.abstract: New study finds that hormone therapy has no effect at all on risk of stroke among women who already have heart disease, but it is not yet known whether finding applies to women who do not have heart disease; is one of several in past few years to challenge widely held belief that estrogen can help ward off heart attacks and strokes in all postmenopausal women (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: During MonaLou Callery's marriage, there were nights when her husband would knock her to the floor and then kick her and choke her until she passed out, or slam her face into the wall, his hand at the back of her head, she later recalled in divorce proceedings against him. In 1983, after six and a half years of abuse, she left him. She found a job, fought for custody of her children and started rebuilding her life. Yet every time she combed her hair or brushed her teeth, the mirror showed a constant reminder of the brutality. Her nose, broken more than 14 times, had settled into a crooked distortion, humped where the bone had scarred.

headline.main: Surgery Heals Scars Both Physical and Emotional

docs.abstract: Dr Mark Rounds and hundreds of other plastic surgeons donate their time and skill to victims of domestic abuse, and their patients get psychological boost from having their facial injuries repaired; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Rick awakened at 2 a.m. with severe gastrointestinal distress, passed out on the way to the bathroom and spent the next two days in bed. The problem, he surmised, was food poisoning from the dozen raw oysters he had eaten that evening at a three-star restaurant. But because he never saw a doctor and did not obtain a stool or blood culture, the case and the causative organism never made it into the record books. And because the restaurant was neither informed nor investigated, chances are Rick was not the only victim of a presumed slip in its food buying and preparation procedures. Each year Americans experience some 200 million episodes of what most people call intestinal flu. Yet more than a third of those ailments, typically characterized by nausea, vomiting and diarrhea, are food poisoning, contracted through something they ate or drank that contained noxious bacteria, viruses, parasites, metals or toxins.

headline.main: The Culprits, When Good Food Goes Bad

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody column on food-borne organisms that can make people ill: Norwalk and Norwalk-like viruses, campylobacter jejuni, salmonella, listeria monocytogenes, vibrio vulnificus and escherichia coli 0157:h7; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Walker Within,'' by the editors of Walking Magazine, Lyons Press, $22.95. The Italians call it a passeggiata, an ages-old village custom in which residents and visitors make a relaxed evening loop around the town, allowing them to visit, if only for a moment, with their neighbors. As one contributor to this thoughtful collection of essays on the simple act of walking puts it, ''Were Americans to take up this custom, the rate of criminal violence would surely drop, for it's easier to gun down strangers than people with whom you've passed the time.''

headline.main: Parade of Witnesses on Wonders of Walking
